title: Nicomachean Ethics
text_original: Every art and every inquiry, and similarly every action and pursuit, is thought to aim at some good; and for this reason the good has rightly been declared to be that at which all things aim.
text_english: Every art and every inquiry, and similarly every action and pursuit, is thought to aim at some good; and for this reason the good has rightly been declared to be that at which all things aim.

title: Nicomachean Ethics
text_original: Virtue, then, is a state of character concerned with choice, lying in a mean, i.e. the mean relative to us, this being determined by reason, and by that reason by which the man of practical wisdom would determine it.
text_english: Virtue, then, is a state of character concerned with choice, lying in a mean, i.e. the mean relative to us, this being determined by reason, and by that reason by which the man of practical wisdom would determine it.

title: Nicomachean Ethics
text_original: Without friends no one would choose to live, though he had all other goods.
text_english: Without friends no one would choose to live, though he had all other goods.

title: Republic
text_original: Speaking the truth and paying back what one has received is not the definition of justice.
text_english: Speaking the truth and paying back what one has received is not the definition of justice.

title: Crito
text_original: We ought not to retaliate or render evil for evil to anyone, whatever evil we may have suffered from him.
text_english: We ought not to retaliate or render evil for evil to anyone, whatever evil we may have suffered from him.

title: Meditations
text_original: Begin the morning by saying to yourself: I shall meet with the busybody, the ungrateful, arrogant, deceitful, envious, unsocial. All these things happen to them by reason of their ignorance of what is good and evil.
text_english: Begin the morning by saying to yourself: I shall meet with the busybody, the ungrateful, arrogant, deceitful, envious, unsocial. All these things happen to them by reason of their ignorance of what is good and evil.

title: Enchiridion
text_original: Some things are in our control and others not. Things in our control are opinion, pursuit, desire, aversion, and, in a word, whatever are our own actions. Things not in our control are body, property, reputation, command, and, in one word, whatever are not our own actions.
text_english: Some things are in our control and others not. Things in our control are opinion, pursuit, desire, aversion, and, in a word, whatever are our own actions. Things not in our control are body, property, reputation, command, and, in one word, whatever are not our own actions.

title: Moral Letters
text_original: I am glad to learn that you live on friendly terms with your slaves. This befits a sensible and well-educated man like yourself. 'They are slaves,' people declare. Nay, rather they are men.
text_english: I am glad to learn that you live on friendly terms with your slaves. This befits a sensible and well-educated man like yourself. 'They are slaves,' people declare. Nay, rather they are men.

title: Digest - Ulpian
text_original: Iuri operam daturum prius nosse oportet, unde nomen iuris descendat. est autem a iustitia appellatum: nam, ut eleganter Celsus definit, ius est ars boni et aequi.
text_english: One who is going to study law ought first to know whence the word 'law' derives. It is called from 'justice'; for, as Celsus elegantly defines it, law is the art of the good and the fair.

title: Digest - Ulpian
text_original: Iustitia est constans et perpetua voluntas ius suum cuique tribuendi.
text_english: Justice is the constant and perpetual will to render to each one his right.

title: Digest - Ulpian
text_original: Iuris praecepta sunt haec: honeste vivere, alterum non laedere, suum cuique tribuere.
text_english: The precepts of the law are these: to live honestly, to harm no one, to give to each his own.

title: Digest - Gaius
text_original: Nullus videtur dolo facere, qui suo iure utitur.
text_english: No one is considered to act with malice who exercises his own right.

title: Digest - Ulpian
text_original: Ait praetor: 'Quod metus causa gestum erit, ratum non habebo.'
text_english: The praetor says: 'What has been done through fear, I will not uphold.'

title: Digest - Ulpian
text_original: Dolum malum Servius quidem ita definiit machinationem quandam alterius decipiendi causa.
text_english: Servius defines fraud as a kind of contrivance to deceive another.

title: Digest - Celsus
text_original: Impossibilium nulla obligatio est.
text_english: There is no obligation to do the impossible.

title: Digest - Ulpian
text_original: Huius edicti aequitas naturalis est.
text_english: The equity of this edict is natural.

title: Digest - Ulpian
text_original: Secundum naturam est commoda cuiusque rei eum sequi, quem sequentur incommoda.
text_english: It is according to nature that the benefits of a thing should follow the one who bears the burdens.

title: Digest - Pomponius
text_original: Nam hoc natura aequum est neminem cum alterius detrimento fieri locupletiorem.
text_english: For by nature it is equitable that no one should be enriched at another's expense.

title: Analects
text_original: 子曰：「參乎！吾道一以貫之。」曾子曰：「唯。」子出，門人問曰：「何謂也？」曾子曰：「夫子之道，忠恕而已矣。」
text_english: The Master said, 'Shen, my doctrine is connected by one thread.' Zengzi said, 'Yes.' When the Master went out, the disciples asked, 'What did he mean?' Zengzi said, 'The doctrine of our master is loyalty and reciprocity (shu), that is all.'

title: Analects
text_original: 仲弓問仁。子曰：「出門如見大賓，使民如承大祭。己所不欲，勿施於人。在邦無怨，在家無怨。」
text_english: Zhonggong asked about benevolence. The Master said, 'When going abroad, behave as if receiving a great guest. When employing people, act as if conducting a great sacrifice. What you do not wish for yourself, do not impose on others.'

title: Analects
text_original: 子貢問曰：「有一言而可以終身行之者乎？」子曰：「其恕乎！己所不欲，勿施於人。」
text_english: Zigong asked, 'Is there one word that can guide a person throughout life?' The Master said, 'How about reciprocity (shu)? What you do not wish for yourself, do not impose on others.'

title: Mencius
text_original: 孟子曰：「萬物皆備於我矣。反身而誠，樂莫大焉。強恕而行，求仁莫近焉。」
text_english: Mencius said, 'All things are complete in us. There is no greater joy than to find sincerity in self-examination. If one acts with conscientiousness and reciprocity, they are not far from benevolence.'

title: Tao Te Ching
text_original: 為無為，事無事，味無味。大小多少，報怨以德。
text_english: Act without action, work without work, taste the tasteless. Regard the small as large, the few as many. Repay injury with kindness.

title: Abhisanda Sutta
text_original: Pāṇātipātā veramaṇī sikkhāpadaṃ samādiyāmi
text_english: I undertake the training rule to abstain from taking life. I undertake the training rule to abstain from taking what is not given. I undertake the training rule to abstain from sexual misconduct. I undertake the training rule to abstain from false speech. I undertake the training rule to abstain from intoxicants.

title: Veludvareyya Sutta
text_original: Attānaṃ upamaṃ katvā, na haneyya na ghātaye
text_english: Comparing oneself to others, one should neither kill nor cause others to kill. All beings tremble before violence. All fear death. Seeing oneself in others, one should neither kill nor cause killing.

title: Dhammapada
text_original: Manopubbaṅgamā dhammā manoseṭṭhā manomayā
text_english: Mind is the forerunner of all actions. All deeds are led by mind, created by mind. If one speaks or acts with a corrupt mind, suffering follows as the wheel follows the hoof of the ox.

title: Dhammapada
text_original: Sabbe tasanti daṇḍassa, sabbe bhāyanti maccuno
text_english: All tremble at punishment; all fear death. Comparing oneself with others, one should neither kill nor cause killing. All tremble at punishment; to all, life is dear. Comparing oneself with others, one should neither kill nor cause killing.

title: Sigalovada Sutta
text_english: There are these four ways of showing love: by gifts, kind words, helpful actions, and treating others as oneself. These four ways of showing love sustain the world like the axle of a rolling chariot.

title: Isha Upanishad
text_original: ईशावास्यमिदं सर्वं यत्किञ्च जगत्यां जगत्
text_english: All this, whatever moves in this moving world, is pervaded by the Lord. Therefore find your enjoyment in renunciation; do not covet what belongs to others.

title: Brihadaranyaka Upanishad
text_original: आत्मानं चेद्विजानीयात्
text_english: If one knows the Self, with 'I am Brahman', becoming everything, even the gods cannot prevent him, for he becomes their Self.

title: Chandogya Upanishad
text_original: तत्त्वमसि
text_english: That thou art. You are that ultimate reality, that Brahman.

metadata.note: Tat Tvam Asi - identity of self and ultimate

title: Katha Upanishad
text_original: नायमात्मा प्रवचनेन लभ्यो न मेधया न बहुना श्रुतेन
text_english: This Self cannot be attained by study, nor by intellect, nor by much learning. It is gained only by one whom It chooses.

title: Mundaka Upanishad
text_original: सत्यमेव जयते
text_english: Truth alone triumphs, not falsehood. By truth is laid out the path leading to the gods.
